thread.title_full: James Bond Movie Campaign Hits Snapchat - WSJ

author: Mike Shields
title: James Bond Movie Campaign Hits Snapchat
text:
0 COMMENTS Snapchat’s Discover section is one of the more exclusive and desired locations in media these days—as only 15 media companies have the privilege of publishing content there.
Therefore, it makes sense that if Snapchat were going to let any marketer join the Discover club, it would be James Bond.
On Monday, the new James Bond movie “Spectre” rolled out its own Snapchat Discover channel, the first time a brand has paid for such treatment, according to a Snapchat spokeswoman.
The “Spectre” channel appears both in the first position of the scrollable list of Discover buttons on the Snapchat Stories page, and in the upper-left corner of the Snapchat Discover page, right next to similar buttons from Refinery29 and Daily Mail.
A photo from the "Spectre" Snapchat Discover channel Photo: Snapchat In fact, the new 007-branded channel, which is labeled as sponsored, pushes the iHeart Radio Discover button down below the “fold” (on an iPhone 6S it gets moved off the screen).
While Snapchat executives have in the past said they are not expecting a big push toward “native advertising” on the popular video and social media application, the “Spectre” Discover channel blends content and pure advertising. Fans can flip through behind-the-scenes footage of the movie, which opens on Nov. 6, answer Bond trivia questions, choose whether they’d prefer a martini shaken or stirred, or watch a testimonial from a “ Spectre ” cast member.
People can invite friends to see the movie with them via the Discover channel. The Bond content is professionally produced and doesn’t incorporate any user-produced videos, which are often a staple of Snapchat brand efforts.
Photo: Snapchat However, in the U.S., U.K. and Canada, fans have access to special “Spectre”-branded images, or filters, which they can use in their own Snapchat videos.
Snapchat said that besides the stand-alone Discover channel, “Spectre” ads are running on other parts of Snapchat.
“We’re huge James Bond fans and excited to give our community a sneak peek into the action,” Nick Bell, head of content at Snapchat, said in a statement.
